questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after falling from her bicycle. The girl was racing with her cousin when she lost control and fell onto her right side. She has nausea and severe pain in the right shoulder. She is in acute distress. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness over the right clavicle and pain exacerbated by movement; range of motion is limited. The skin over the clavicle is intact. The radial pulse in the right arm is intact. Sensory examination of the right upper limb shows no abnormalities. An x‑ray of the chest is shown. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's shoulder?

choices.text: Obtain an MRI of the right shoulder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tension band wiring using K-wires is performed for unstable lateral clavicle fractures, which have an increased risk of nonunion. Tension band wiring is not the treatment of choice for midshaft fractures.

B) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a midclavicular fracture, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with a clavicular plate is indicated only in the presence of one of the following: tenting and blanching of the overlying skin, open fracture, severe displacement or > 2 cm of shortening, neurovascular injury, floating shoulder injury, or established nonunion. For nondisplaced midclavicular fractures, ORIF is not indicated; these fractures typically heal well, and surgery might actually increase the incidence of delayed union or nonunion.

C) INCORRECT:

A shoulder spica cast is not the technique of choice for shoulder immobilization in a patient with a clavicular fracture. This cast is bulky, difficult to apply, does not allow early physiotherapy, and is associated with an increased risk of adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).

D) CORRECT:

Conservative treatment with a simple shoulder sling for 4–8 weeks is the treatment of choice for nondisplaced midshaft fractures of the clavicle because these fractures typically heal very well without significant intervention. After 2–4 weeks, physiotherapy should be initiated. Excessively shortened or displaced fractures require surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

For unstable clavicular fractures, a plain MRI of the shoulder is used to assess the conoid and trapezoid ligaments (coracoclavicular ligaments), the acromioclavicular joint, and the sternoclavicular joint. However, injury to these structures is unlikely in this patient, since she has an isolated midclavicular fracture from low-energy trauma.

F) INCORRECT:

Arteriography is only indicated if injury to the subclavian vessels is suspected (e.g., if radial or brachial pulses are weak or a bruit over the fracture site is heard). Since peripheral pulses are intact in this patient, arteriography is not required. In addition, injury to subclavian vessels following a clavicular fracture due to blunt trauma is extremely rare.
questions.hint: This patient has shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and tenderness and swelling over the clavicle. The skin is intact, and there is no evidence of neurovascular damage. The x-ray shows a nondisplaced midshaft fracture of the clavicle.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe left shoulder pain following a fall onto his left shoulder while skiing. He took 400 mg of ibuprofen on his way to the emergency department. He appears in acute distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Examination of the left shoulder shows a visibly elevated left clavicle with tenderness and crepitus on palpation. Left shoulder active and passive range of motion are limited by pain. The radial pulses are palpable, and there is no loss of sensation to light touch in the left arm, hand, or shoulder. An x-ray of the left shoulder is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Bed rest, ice, and ibuprofen intake
CT scan of the chest and left shoulder
Physical therapy with restricted range of motion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rest, ice, and ibuprofen are a good first measure for a number of musculoskeletal injuries (e.g., sprained ankle). This patient's x-ray, however, reveals a displaced fracture of the clavicle. Even though rest, ice, and pain management would be part of his treatment, the fracture also requires some form of stabilization, at least with an arm sling.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan is appropriate for medial physeal clavicular, sternal injuries, or if x-ray is inconclusive. However, the x-ray findings clearly show a fracture of the lateral clavicle and the patient is 24 years old, meaning that his growth plates have already fused.

C) INCORRECT:

While physical therapy will be part of the long term management of this patient's clavicle fracture (to avoid adhesions and atrophy), it should not be initiated until the fracture has been stabilized and allowed to heal.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative management through immobilization with a shoulder sling is appropriate for nondisplaced clavicle fractures or a fracture with displacement of less than one bone width. The shoulder sling stabilizes the bone fragments by restricting motion of the shoulder. But the x-ray of this patient's fracture reveals a completely displaced lateral clavicle fracture, which means that conservative management would be an inadequate next step and likely result in nonunion.
Image Description:

X-ray right clavicle (AP view) of a child after a recent fall on an outstretched arm

A subtle nondisplaced fracture (green overlay) is seen at the mid to medial third of the right clavicle. There is no callus formation.

Arrowheads: overlying artefact; red overlay: growth plate

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a completely displaced lateral clavicle fracture on x-ray, likely with a torn conoid ligament. A completely displaced clavicle fracture involves displacement greater than one bone width and requires surgical management. Surgical intervention for completely displaced clavicle fracture results in lower rates of nonunion when compared with conservative management through immobilization alone. Other indications for surgical intervention include open fractures, neurovascular compromise, and tenting of the skin.
Image Description:

The Allman classification divides the clavicle into three equal segments, according to which fractures are classified.
questions.hint: As with all fractures, the severity of displacement is one of the most important factors when choosing between conservative or operative management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a bicycling accident. He complains of severe pain over the front of his right shoulder. He refuses to move his right arm. Physical examination shows supraclavicular swelling and bruising. The shoulder's range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the shoulder shows a fracture of the middle third of the clavicle with complete superior displacement of the medial clavicular segment. Which of the following muscles is responsible for the displacement of this segment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The superior fibers of the trapezius originate at the external occipital protuberance and nuchal ligament, and insert into the posterior border of the lateral third of the clavicle. In the setting of a clavicular fracture, the trapezius would pull the lateral clavicular fragment both superiorly and posteriorly. Although the trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve, a different muscle would be responsible for superior displacement of the medial clavicle.

B) INCORRECT:

The deltoid muscle attaches to the humerus and the anterior border of the lateral third of the clavicle. In the setting of a clavicular fracture, the deltoid muscle would therefore pull the lateral clavicular segment downwards.

C) INCORRECT:

The subclavius muscle originates from the first rib and inserts onto the inferior surface of the clavicle. In the setting of a clavicular fracture, it would therefore pull the clavicle downwards.

D) INCORRECT:

The pectoralis major muscle originates at the sternum and medial half of the clavicle and inserts at the humerus. In the setting of a clavicular fracture with an intact acromioclavicular joint and glenohumeral joint, this muscle would cause medial displacement of the lateral clavicular segment.

E) CORRECT:

The sternocleidomastoid muscle is superiorly attached to the mastoid process and inferiorly attached to the medial third of the clavicle. Therefore, in the setting of a fracture, as seen in this patient, the sternocleidomastoid pulls the medial segment of the fractured clavicle upwards.
Image Description:

The junction of the medial second third and the lateral first third is the most common site of clavicle fractures, as depicted here. Distracting forces cause a downward dislocation of the lateral fracture fragment and an upward dislocation of the medial fracture fragment, resulting in the following clinical features:

- Sagging of the ipsilateral shoulder due to downward distracting force of the weight of the upper limb on the lateral fracture fragment
- Shortening of the ipsilateral shoulder due to the medial distracting force of the pectoralis major on the lateral fracture fragment
- Tenting of the skin over the fracture site due to the upward distracting force of the sternocleidomastoid on the medial fracture fragment
questions.hint: The muscle in question is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve and functions predominantly in the rotation of the head.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl presents with shoulder pain after a fall from her bicycle. She lost her balance while making a sharp turn, fell to the left, and landed on the lateral aspect of her shoulder with her arm at her side. She experienced sharp pain and noticed a deformity over the superior aspect of her shoulder.
There is a tender deformity of the left clavicle. The overlying skin is swollen but intact, except for a few abrasions. Pain makes her unable to abduct her arm beyond 45 degrees. She has 5/5 strength of her elbow, wrist, and hand. Her peripheral pulses are intact, and she has full sensation in her left upper extremity.
A radiograph reveals a fracture of the midportion of the clavicle. Superior translation of the medial fragment is less than the width of the clavicle and exhibits 10 mm of shortening.
Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Referral for open reduction with internal fixation
Manual reduction followed by immobilization with a sling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical indications for a middle-third clavicle fracture include an open fracture, neurovascular compromise, complete displacement, or shortening of more than 15 to 20 mm.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy is likely to be painful during the period immediately after the facture.

C) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction is not indicated for a fracture that is displaced less than 15 to 20 mm.

D) CORRECT:

Middle-third clavicle fractures are the most common type of clavicle fractures. When the fracture is only minimally displaced (as in this case), it can typically be managed nonoperatively with immobilization, preferably with a sling.

A figure-of-eight brace has been used for treatment of clavicle fractures, but it may be less well tolerated early in the course of the treatment.

Lateral-third clavicle fractures are the second most common clavicle fractures. Although nonoperative treatment is provided for most of these fractures, treatment recommendations are specific to each subtype, and consultation with an orthopedic surgeon should always be considered.

Medial-third clavicle fractures are the least common clavicle fractures. These are often high-mechanism injuries and can be associated with pneumothorax, hemothorax, pulmonary contusion, and soft-tissue injuries of the head and neck. Most are managed nonoperatively with ice, analgesics, and a sling for support.

Key learning point: A middle-third clavicle fracture with mild displacement and <15 mm of shortening can be treated with immobilization using a sling.

E) INCORRECT:

A long-arm cast would immobilize the elbow, the wrist, and the radius and ulna, but it would not immobilize the clavicle.

questions.text:
A healthy, right-hand-dominant 11-year-old boy with no significant medical history presents to clinic for evaluation of right-clavicle pain. He reports that during football practice, he went for a tackle and fell onto the superior aspect of his shoulder. He heard a cracking sound and felt immediate pain in the middle-third of his collarbone. The pain is exacerbated by abduction and cross-body reaching with the affected arm; it is alleviated by wearing a sling. The patient has no numbness or tingling, loss of sensation, neck pain, elbow pain, wrist pain, hand pain, ecchymosis, or shortness of breath.
A radiograph is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Referral to orthopedic surgery for operative repair
Return to football practice for 2 weeks and then return to full participation as tolerated
Immobilization with a sling for 2 weeks, followed by gentle range of motion starting at 2 weeks
Manual reduction with application of a splint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The general consensus is to seek orthopedic referral if there is neurovascular injury, skin tenting, open fracture, or >2 cm of shortening of the clavicle. The extent of shortening is measured between the medial fragment end and the lateral fragment end. This patient sustained a middle-third clavicle fracture that is displaced and 1.9 cm shortened. Given that the extent of shortening is <2 cm, the fracture should be managed conservatively.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy, with a focus on shoulder-strengthening exercises, should be initiated at week 6. Return to play with full participation (including practice) does not typically occur until 3 months after injury.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient should be transitioned out of the sling at 2 weeks, with initiation of gradual range-of-motion exercises for weeks 2 to 4. Physical therapy, with a focus on shoulder-strengthening exercises, should be initiated at week 6. Return to play with full participation (including practice) does not typically occur until 3 months after injury.

D) CORRECT:

Clavicle fractures constitute up to 15% of pediatric fractures; mid-shaft clavicle fractures are the most common. Typically, a clavicle fracture is sustained by either direct trauma to the superior aspect of the shoulder or a fall on an outstretched arm. The medial fragment of the fractured clavicle is pulled posterosuperiorly by the sternocleidomastoid muscle while the lateral fragment is pulled inferomedially by the pectoralis and the weight of the arm. Definitive diagnosis of a clavicle fracture is made using plain-film radiographs, with careful evaluation for other associated conditions, including scapular fracture, scapulothoracic dissociation, pneumothorax, and neurovascular injury.

Pediatric clavicle fractures, even those with significant displacement, have a high potential for complete union without reduction or surgical intervention because of bone remodeling that occurs within the immature skeleton. Thus, surgical repair of clavicle fractures in the pediatric population is controversial. The general consensus is to seek orthopedic referral if there is neurovascular injury, skin tenting, open fracture, or >2 cm of shortening of the clavicle. The extent of shortening is measured between the medial fragment end and the lateral fragment end.

Given that the extent of shortening is <2 cm, the fracture should be managed conservatively with immobilization of the arm in a sling or figure-of-eight bandage for 2 weeks. No attempt should be made to reduce the displaced fracture, because any manipulation increases the likelihood of injury to the surrounding neurovascular bundle.

Clavicle fractures are immobilized with a sling. The patient should be transitioned out of the sling at 2 weeks, with initiation of gradual range-of-motion exercises for weeks 2 to 4. Physical therapy, with a focus on shoulder-strengthening exercises, should be initiated at week 6. Return to play with full participation (including practice) does not typically occur until 3 months after injury.

Key learning point: A mid-shaft clavicle fracture with displacement and radiographic evidence of >2 cm (>20 mm) of shortening requires orthopedic surgical evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

No attempt should be made to reduce the displaced fracture, because any manipulation increases the likelihood of injury to the surrounding neurovascular bundle. Although casts and splints may be used to immobilize other long-bone fractures, clavicle fractures are immobilized with a sling.

questions.text: A 28-year-old mountain biker presents after crashing and landing on his right shoulder. He reports immediate pain and difficulty lifting his arm. Physical examination shows right shoulder sagging, focal tenderness over the midshaft clavicle, and 2.5 cm of shortening. There is no skin tenting or open wounds. Neurovascular examination shows intact sensation and normal radial pulses bilaterally. Chest examination is normal. X-ray shows a displaced, comminuted midshaft clavicle fracture with significant shortening but no other injuries. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Arm sling immobilization with orthopedic follow-up
CT angiography to evaluate for vascular injury
Immediate orthopedic consultation for surgical fixation
MRI to assess soft tissue injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Most clavicle fractures are managed conservatively, but this patient has significant shortening (> 2 cm), which is associated with a high risk of malunion or nonunion.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is indicated if there is clinical suspicion of vascular injury, such as weak or absent pulses or signs of ischemia. This patient has normal bilateral radial pulses and an intact neurovascular examination.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a displaced, comminuted midshaft clavicle fracture with significant shortening (> 2 cm). These features indicate a high risk for malunion or nonunion, and therefore orthopedic consultation for surgical fracture management is required.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI is not routinely indicated for clavicle fractures and would not change management in this case. MRI may be considered for assessing intra-articular or ligamentous injury in high-grade acromioclavicular separations.

E) INCORRECT:

In cases in which conservative management is appropriate, current recommendations favor arm sling immobilization, not figure-of-eight bandaging. In addition, this patient requires surgical evaluation due to the degree of shortening and comminution.
